sn4.20:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans, in a wilderness hut in the Himalayan region.
sn4.20:4.2: Then as he was in private solitude this thought came to his mind:
sn4.20:4.3: “I wonder if it’s possible to rule legitimately, without killing or having someone kill for you; without conquering or having someone conquer for you; without sorrowing or causing sorrow?”
sn4.20:5.1: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing what the Buddha was thinking,
sn4.20:5.2: went up to him and said:
sn4.20:5.3: “Rule, Blessed One! Rule, Holy One! Rule legitimately, without killing or having someone kill for you; without conquering or having someone conquer for you; without sorrowing or causing sorrow!”
sn4.20:5.4: “But what do you see, Wicked One, that you say this to me?”
sn4.20:5.6: “The Blessed One, sir, has developed and practiced the four bases for psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them.
sn4.20:5.7: If he wished, the Blessed One need only determine that the Himalaya, king of mountains, was gold, and it would turn into gold.”
sn4.20:6.2: made entirely of gold, and double it—
sn4.20:6.3: it’s still not enough for one!
sn4.20:6.4: Knowing this, live a moral life.
sn4.20:7.1: When a person has seen where suffering comes from
sn4.20:7.2: how could they incline towards sensual pleasures?
sn4.20:7.3: Realizing that attachment is a tie in the world,
sn4.20:7.4: a person would train to remove it.”
sn4.20:8.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
